<|endoftext|>/* Input to this function is a string containing multiple groups of nested parentheses. Your goal is to
  separate those group into separate strings and return the list of those.
  Separate groups are balanced (each open brace is properly closed) and not nested within each other
  Ignore any spaces in the input string.
  >>> separate_paren_groups('( ) (( )) (( )( ))')
  ['()', '(())', '(()())']
  */
const separate_paren_groups = (paren_string) => {
  const paren_groups = paren_string.match(/\(([^()]+)\)/g);
  const paren_group_strings = [];
  for (let i = 0; i < paren_groups.length; i++) {
    const paren_group = paren_groups[i];
    const paren_group_string = '';
    for (let j = 0; j < paren_group.length; j++) {
      if (j === 0) paren_group_string += paren_group[j];
      if (j === paren_group.length - 1) paren_group_string += ')';
    }
    paren_group_strings.push(paren_group_string);
  }
  return paren_group_strings;
};

  console.assert(JSON.stringify(factorize(3 * 19)) === JSON.stringify([3, 19]))

      JSON.stringify([3, 3, 3, 19, 19, 19])

  console.assert(
    JSON.stringify(factorize(3 * 19 * 19 * 19)) ===
      JSON.stringify([3, 19, 19, 19])
  )
  console.assert(
    JSON.stringify(factorize(3 * 2 * 3)) === JSON.stringify([2, 3, 3])
  )
}

<|endoftext|>/* From a list of integers, remove all elements that occur more than once.
  Keep order of elements left the same as in the input.
  >>> remove_duplicates([1, 2, 3, 2, 4])
  [1, 3, 4]
  */
const remove_duplicates = (numbers) => {
  const seen = new Set();
  const result = [];
  for (let i = 0; i < numbers.length; i++) {
    const number = numbers[i];
    if (seen.has(number)) {
      continue;
    }
    seen.add(number);
    result.push(number);
  }
  return result;
};

/**
 * A function to convert a number to a string in base 10.
 * >>> to_base10(12345)
 '12345'
 */
const to_base10 = (number) => {
  let result = '';
  while (number > 0) {
    const digit = number % 10;
    number = Math.floor(number / 10);
    result += digit;
  }
  return result;
};

  false

  >>> correct_bracketing("><<>")

  */
const correct_bracketing = (brackets) => {
  const opening_brackets = brackets.split("<");
  const closing_brackets = brackets.split(">");
  return opening_brackets.every(opening => closing_brackets.every(closing => opening === closing));
};

}

  )

  Examples:
  strange_sort_list([1, 2, 3, 4]) == [1, 4, 2, 3]
  strange_sort_list([5, 5, 5, 5]) == [5, 5, 5, 5]
  strange_sort_list([]) == []
  */
const strange_sort_list = (lst) => {
  let sorted = lst.sort((a, b) => a - b);
  let res = [];
  for (let i = 0; i < sorted.length; i++) {
    if (sorted[i] > sorted[i + 1]) {
      res.push(sorted[i]);
    }
  }
  return res;
};

  length is a prime number or false otherwise
  Examples
  prime_length('Hello') == true
  prime_length('abcdcba') == true
  prime_length('kittens') == true
  prime_length('orange') == false
  */
const prime_length = (string) => {
  let prime = true;
  let length = string.length;
  for (let i = 2; i <= length; i++) {
    if (string.charAt(i) === string.charAt(length - i)) {
      prime = false;
      break;
    }
  }
  return prime;
};

  [1, 15, 33]
  >>> unique_digits([152, 323, 1422, 10])
  []
  */
const unique_digits = (x) => {
  let result = [];
  let digit = 0;
  let digits = [];
  
  for (let i = 0; i < x.length; i++) {
    if (x[i] % 2 === 0) {
      digits.push(x[i]);
    } else {
      digit = 0;
    }
    
    while (digit < digits.length) {
      if (digits[digit] === 0) {
        digits[digit] = 1;
        digit += 1;
      } else {
        digit = 0;
      }
    }
    
    if (digit === digits.length) {
      result.push(digit);
    }
  }
  
  return result;
};

      'Eight',
      'Five',
      'Four',
      'Three',

  )

<|endoftext|>/*
  Given a non-empty array of integers arr and an integer k, return
  the sum of the elements with at most two digits from the first k elements of arr.

  Example:

      Input: arr = [111,21,3,4000,5,6,7,8,9], k = 4
      Output: 24 # sum of 21 + 3

  Constraints:
      1. 1 <= len(arr) <= 100
      2. 1 <= k <= len(arr)
  */
const add_elements = (arr, k) => {
  let sum = 0;
  let i = 0;
  let j = 0;
  let carry = 0;
  while (i < arr.length) {
    if (arr[i] >= 10) {
      sum += arr[i] * Math.pow(10, k - j);
      carry = 0;
      j++;
    } else {
      sum += arr[i];
      carry++;
    }
    i++;
  }
  return sum + carry;
};

// https://leetcode.com/problems/find-the-sum-of-two-digits-in-an-integer/
/**
 * Definition for singly-linked list.
 * function ListNode(val) {
 *     this.val = val;
 *     this.next = null;
 * }
 */
/**
 * @param {ListNode} head
 * @param {number} k
 * @return {number}
 */
var findSumOfTwoDigits = function(head, k) {
  let sum = 0;
  let curr = head;
  while (curr) {
    if (curr.val <= 9) {
      sum += curr.val;
      curr = curr.next;
    } else {
      curr = curr.next;
    }
  }
  return sum + findSumOfTwoDigits(head, k - 1);
};

/*
  Given a positive integer n, return a sorted list that has the odd numbers in collatz sequence.

  The Collatz conjecture is a conjecture in mathematics that concerns a sequence defined
  as follows: start with any positive integer n. Then each term is obtained from the 
  previous term as follows: if the previous term is even, the next term is one half of 
  the previous term. If the previous term is odd, the next term is 3 times the previous
  term plus 1. The conjecture is that no matter what value of n, the sequence will always reach 1.

  Note: 
      1. Collatz(1) is [1].
      2. returned list sorted in increasing order.

  For example:
  get_odd_collatz(5) returns [1, 5] # The collatz sequence for 5 is [5, 16, 8, 4, 2, 1], so the odd numbers are only 1, and 5.

  console.assert(JSON.stringify(tri(1)) === JSON.stringify([1, 3]))
}

<|endoftext|>/*Given an integer. return a tuple that has the number of even and odd digits respectively.

   Example:
      even_odd_count(-12) ==> (1, 1)
      even_odd_count(123) ==> (1, 2)
  */
const even_odd_count = (num) => {
  let even = 0;
  let odd = 0;
  let digit;
  do {
    digit = num % 10;
    num = Math.floor(num / 10);
    even = even + digit % 2;
    odd = odd + digit / 2;
  } while (num > 0);
  return [even, odd];
};

 * i + 1.
 */
const ascii_encode_except_1 = str => {
  let result = '';
  for (let i = 0; i < str.length; i++) {
    if (i!== str.length - 1 && i!== str.length - 2) {
      result += String.fromCharCode(str.charCodeAt(i));
    } else {
      result += str[i];
    }
  }
  return result;
};

/**
 * Given a string, return the string with every character replaced by its
 * ASCII code except the character at index i, except the character at index
 * i + 1, except the character at index i + 2.
 */
const ascii_encode_except_2 = str => {
  let result = '';
  for (let i = 0; i < str.length; i++) {
    if (i!== str.length - 1 && i!== str.length - 2 &&
        i!== str.length - 3) {
      result += String.fromCharCode(str.charCodeAt(i));
    } else {
      result += str[i];
    }
  }
  return result;
};
